sanavesa.net

Class Client

  • java.lang.Object
    • sanavesa.net.Client

  • public class Client
extends java.lang.Object
    The Client class is the back-end foundation for the client-server architecture. It contains the essential features required to represent a client. To fully utilize this class' capabilities, it is preferable to extend the class to fine-tune the client.
    Since:
    1.0
    Author:
    Mohammad Alali

    • Field Detail

      • TIMEOUT_DURATION

        private static int TIMEOUT_DURATION
        The duration in milliseconds for connection timeout. Default value is 5 seconds.

      • communicationThread

        private java.lang.Thread communicationThread
        The client's own thread to handle incoming and outgoing communication.

      • connected

        private volatile boolean connected
        A flag of whether the client is connected.

        private NetworkCommunication networkCommunication
        The communication for the socket.

      • socket

        private java.net.Socket socket
        The client's socket.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Client

        public Client()
        Constructs a new Client instance. The constructor sets up the shutdown hook for when the client is terminated unexpectedly by disconnecting from the server. It will terminate the connection and its streams, and stop the communication thread.
        Since:
        1.1

    • Method Detail

      • getTimeoutDuration

        public static int getTimeoutDuration()
        Gets the timeout duration for blocking until a connection is established or an error occurs. A duration value of 0 is interpreted as an infinite duration. The value returned can not be negative; only zero and positive integers are allowed.
        Returns:
        the timeout duration in milliseconds
        Since:
        1.1
        See Also:
        connect(String, int)

      • setTimeoutDuration

        public static void setTimeoutDuration(int duration)
        Sets the timeout duration for blocking until a connection is established or an error occurs. A duration value of 0 is interpreted as an infinite duration.
        Parameters:
        duration - - the timeout value to be used in milliseconds
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - - thrown when duration is a negative value
        Since:
        1.1
        See Also:
        connect(String, int)

      • connect

        public final void connect(java.lang.String ipAddress,
                          int port)
        Connects the client instance to the specified hostName and port. If the client is already connected to any connection, this method will abort early and do nothing. The following methods will get triggered:
        • onConnected(String, int) - if the connection was successful
        • onFailedToConnect(String, int) - if the connection was a failure
        Parameters:
        ipAddress - - the IP address to connect to
        port - - the port to connect to
        Since:
        1.0

      • disconnect

        public final void disconnect()
        Disconnect the client from the server. If already disconnected, the method will terminate early and do nothing. The onDisconnected(String, int) method will be triggered on a successful disconnection.
        Since:
        1.0

      • disconnect

        final void disconnect(boolean notifyDisconnection)
        Disconnect the client from the server. The parameter notifyDisconnection is used as follows:
        • true - if the disconnection request was made locally.
        • false - if disconnection request was made remotely.
        Parameters:
        notifyDisconnection - - a flag of whether the disconnection request was made locally or remotely
        Since:
        1.0

      • isConnected

        public final boolean isConnected()
        Returns the connection status of the client.
        Returns:
        true if the client is connected to the server; false otherwise
        Since:
        1.0

      • onConnected

        protected void onConnected(java.lang.String ipAddress,
                           int port)
        This method is triggered automatically when the client has successfully connected to a server via the connect(String, int) method.
        Parameters:
        ipAddress - - the IP address of the server we connected to
        port - - the port of the server we connected to
        Since:
        1.0

      • onDisconnected

        protected void onDisconnected(java.lang.String ipAddress,
                              int port)
        This method is triggered automatically when the client has successfully disconnected from a server via the disconnect() method. Avoid using System.exit(int) in this method.
        Parameters:
        ipAddress - - the IP address of the server we disconnected from
        port - - the port of the server we disconnected from
        Since:
        1.0

      • onFailedToConnect

        protected void onFailedToConnect(java.lang.String ipAddress,
                                 int port)
        This method is triggered automatically when the client has failed to connect to a server via the connect(String, int) method.
        Parameters:
        ipAddress - - the attempted IP address of the server
        port - - the attempted port of the server
        Since:
        1.0

      • onReceivedData

        private <T extends NetworkSerializable> void onReceivedData(T data)
        This method is triggered automatically when the client has received data from the server. The data received is a class that implements the NetworkSerializable interface. The data received is handled by the interface via the NetworkSerializable.handleOnClient(Client) method.
        Type Parameters:
        T - - the class type of the data received
        Parameters:
        data - - the data object received from the server
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        NetworkSerializable

      • resetInstance

        private final void resetInstance()
        Used internally to reset the instance's variables. It will terminate the connection and its streams, and stop the communication thread.
        Since:
        1.0

      • run

        final void run()
        The run method handles the incoming networking transmission. This method should never be explicitly called as it automatically handled by the ClientThread class, which calls this method on a separate thread.

        Incoming data will trigger the onReceivedData(NetworkSerializable) method, where the user is able to override and handle the data as he or she wishes.

        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        ClientThread

      • sendData

        public final <T extends NetworkSerializable> void sendData(T data)
                                                    throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                                                           java.lang.NullPointerException,
                                                           java.lang.RuntimeException
        Sends the specified data object to the server.
        Type Parameters:
        T - - the class type of the data to send
        Parameters:
        data - - the data to send to the server
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown when the parameter data is null.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown when the connection's output stream is null.
        java.lang.RuntimeException - thrown when facing issues writing to the connection's output stream.
        Since:
        1.1

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a nicely formatted string representation of the client object along with its connection status.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        formatted string of the client object
        Since:
        1.1
